1110912110366724096.text: Not only will PoS devices basically be more programmable to enable QR code / NFT invoices that are interoperable with different payment streams, but it will be extremely easy for Apple or Samsung to move off the four-party payments model onto a purely blockchain system.

1110912108173115392.text: Once mobile payment instruments are widely adopted and related infrastructure is in place to support it, it will be far easier for blockchain-based payment solutions (whether cryptocurrency, tokens, or other), to be adopted at point-of-sale.

1110912105971097600.text: This will in turn drive adoption and deployment of compatible PoS devices that merchants and consumers become comfortable with over time. It won't happen overnight, but will likely happen faster than it took for payment cards to diffuse through economy.

1110912104175976448.text: Samsung and Apple are now getting into the payments business but not doing away with these payment rails entirely, they are using them initially but slowly transitioning consumers into a mobile-only payments world by first tokenising the card payment instrument onto mobile.

1110912102011686912.text: 70 years later payment cards are widely adopted and the infrastructure to enable this payment instrument is widely adopted. It *only* took around 70 years for payment cards to become this widely accepted, with huge investment and capital deployment to get here.

1110912099767603201.text: What's important about this is that payment cards first launched in 1950s and took this long to become almost universally accepted. In early days of payment cards there were numerous problems related to clearing and settlement, fraud, security, etc. This hindered adoption.

1110912096810819584.text: Apple Card & Samsung Pay both tokenize card payment instrument to enable card-not-present payment instructions. Means these payments run through the four party payments model. Payer still instructs his bank to make payment to payee's bank account, via payment system operator.pic.twitter.com/2nGWEUQRTn

1110912094428368898.text: My takeaway from Apple Card launch is changing form factor of payments. Samsung and Apple are taking card-not-present payment instructions mainstream and making it 2nd nature to pay w/mobile. This is critical if cryptocurrency payment methods are ever to go mainstream. >thread>

1040260473164312577.text: 6/ Back to fiat tx's (point 4). This is why digital fiat transactions mostly clear only after two days. If you create instant clearing and settlement by using blockchain payment rails, it will complicate a bank's treasury function and may create risks to financial stability.

1040260470639341568.text: 5/ As a side note, central banks actively manage a liquidity shortfall in interbank mkt in order to set its policy interest rates. The shortfall in interbank mkt forces banks to borrow from central bank at the repurchase rate, aka the Repo /Policy rate.

1040260467808239618.text: 4/ But it's bigger than that. A fiat transaction from one bank to another means a liability is extinguished with one bank and created with another. This gives rise to the interbank market where long/short liability positions are funded.

1040260465207795713.text: 3/ Also, the business case & risk of replacing a ledger varies by bank. So if you're going to put *a* ledger on a blockchain, you need to hope that risk/opportunity aligns with other banks, which is unlikely. Otherwise you're running a single node blockchain, which is pointless.

1040260461680373760.text: 2/ Eg. A fiat deposit in a transactional account sits in different ledger than a savings account. These accounts are liabilities to a bank, as opposed to a home loan that is an asset. Which ledger do you start with, because you can't do all at once?

1040260459201474560.text: 1/ People who think that commercial bank ledgers will be moved onto blockchain have no idea how a) complicated and hence risky that is to do, and b) don't know that each bank runs hundreds of different ledgers that is each optimised for specific products or use-cases.
